Posts.Content: LiziX All the very best wishes to you. I hope you have plenty of family support with the children. May I ask how you found this place so quickly? I have been following the Walking back to happiness thread and am so impressed and encouraged by the support and help the participants give each other. I haven't actually experienced chemotherapy myself, but there are many who have and it seems that treatments and methods have improved so much in recent years.
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed with breast cancer:-(

Posts.Content: LeoLady You do write the most lovely, thoughtful, warm  and encouraging posts. This one to LiziX brings tears to my eyes, but that doesn't matter. Thank you very much and the very best of luck with your chemo. When my daughter-in-law had chemo about six years ago and decided to shave her head as soon as her hair started coming out, my granddaughters bought her a selection of scarves.  If I remember correctly, I think they were made specially for the purpose.
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed with breast cancer:-(

Posts.Content: LeoLady *blush emoticon here* I blame synthetic Dave who does not read me the punctuation or things like forward slash!! I'm not quite sure where to click for 'confirm friend', but take it as yes please!
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed with breast cancer:-(

Posts.Content: LeoLady I have just re-read the e-mail notification and note that you joined this site in 1017! :) So that gave me a smile - definitely a smile-inducing typo.
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed with breast cancer:-(

Posts.Content: Ansti All good wishes to you. I think it is always best to know as much as possible, although I know people who prefer not to know. I joined here to ask a specific question (about Letrozole with cancer) and found it interesting and reassuring to hear from those who have such an experience.
Posts.Title: Surgery in 10 days, then .... no idea

Posts.Content: Reading via e-mail notification as usual. It is always very interesting to hear what's going on. Today though I have received multiple copies of two of the e-mails!  Well I suppose you can't have too much of a good thing! :) Nothing interesting to report as far as the cancer is concerned - I just take the Letrozole every day - but various other scans etc have shown all is well and I am taking less blood pressure medication, so that's good.  And keeping moving of course ...
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: The Surgeon said that the lump has shrunk a bit more and the tiny extra lump is no longer there. She considered out loud whether to 'pop it out' under a local anaesthetic, but came down on the side of leave well alone ... and come back in a year. She said I looked much better than I did six months ago, but I think that is because heart and blood pressure medication has been adjusted so that probably accounst for it! If I could take and post photos, I'd put one in of my neighbour's beautiful dahlia  which is light purply colour and is covered with blooms and the plant is large enough for me to sort of see from my lounge window.
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: seaspirit Yes, definitely keep walking!! It is amazing how slight rises in gradient are so much more noticeable now I am a bit older!
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Cannon May I ask - how long you have been on Letrozole?
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Seaspirit44 Thank you for the further information which is very helpful. I really admire the way you evidently have been, and still are, dealing with everything. On the subject of osteoporosis, I had a scan just over four years ago after I had had pelvic cracks and fractured vertebrae after being knocked down by a car! The osteoporosis was mild, but I too have been on Alendronic Acid and the Calceo plus, twice-daily crunchy calcium tablets since then! Every now and again I take a break from these!!
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Cannon Thank you  - yes, it is encouraging to have a smaller tumour!    Seaspirit44  Thank you that is interesting to hhear you have been taking them for more than 8 years. Did you have many side effects early on? They have only started during the past couple of months really, but it’s a case of weighing up the pros and cons I suppose!  I feel very well most of the  time.   This morning I walked about 2.5 miles, but had to walk slower than usual Tut-tutting and grumgling! And I had to pause for regular rests, but at no time was I exhausted,dizzy, out of breath or unable to go on. Legs working fine, just the sort of ache mainly in upper body.  When I got home I did not have to sit down or anything. Very frustrating!!
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Mirabo I always note posts which mention Letrozole! I hope you manage all right on it and will look out for any comments you might make on its effects, if any.  I have been on them now since April last year.
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Cannon Unfortunately, I did not have an op - In view of my age (82) and those things they call 'morbidities'!, the Surgeon is relying on the medication. Small, non-aggressive tumour has definitely shrunk, but I shal be interested to see what the surgeon says. (I'm not sure whether she should be called a Consultant.)
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Leolady reading your posts and all the others when they come through as e-mail notifications is such a morale boost each day. I think you are all amazing. I found out last week that symptoms I had thought might be connected with the Letrozole (e.g. on Thursday morning I was so dizzy, I had to sit on the floor and phone 111) are in fact to do with heart. I've almost certainly acquired angina. An exercise ECG at Southampton soon then I might have to  modify my walking and gym visits! I'll probably have to sit down occasionally at tap dancing - shoc, horror!! :)
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Seaspirit44, moony and Leolady56   Thank you for your kind comments. Yes, after training as a mature student, I was a Primary School teacher for 20 years. I like to think that the things I did well outweighed the mistakes! One boy said to me once, ‘Well, you encourage us, Miss.’
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Weeblemun :D  Slight difference!! I've never tried olive bread - must remember to do so I enjoy reading the words of all the posts as usual. Yesterday, I went to the Southampton Chest Pain Clinic (and by the way the General's entrance has been modernised amazingly - a bit like goin from mid 20th Century - to 21st in one leap! - I could perceive enough to be very impressed. ECG and Echo-Cardiogram. Doctor said to go back onto beta blockers - I was told to stop taking them about 15 months ago. When I got home and phoned the surgery to say, they said the hospital had already phoned them. I was so impressed and grateful for that. I had pretty much worked out that it wasn't the Letrozole causing the dizziness and tightness in the chest, but it is nice to have things clear and I hope to be walking at a brisk pace again soon. I hope those of you on chemo or radio therapy have a restful weekend and that the weather is kind.
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Weeb;e,im thank you for your reply. I seem to get a few of those symptoms - plus a few different ones too!
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Weeblemun Thank you for your reply. May I ask what the tachycardia felt like? (I hope this is not too much of a tangent on this thread.)
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: I expect everyone has been out and about today - the weather makes such a difference to how we feel,, doesn't it.  I walked - rather slowly but got to the café at the cliff top. Sun sparkling on sea with The Needles on the horizon.
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Just posting to ensure remaining logged in! It is always such a positive thing to read all your walking posts. e thing reading all your walking posts.
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Gingerly try to apologise for double post ... this one might appear twice too.. hmmm
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Following posts on e-mails as usual. LeoLady: glad you have finished your chemo and I hope the hair doesn't take too long to grow back. I walked to /Barton again this morning and took ten minutes less time than last week! When my granddaughter and partner visited on Wednesday, the sun was shining and although it was a bit of a cool breeze, we were able to walk down to the lower path by the cliff and then have a pot of tea at the Beachcomber.
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: seaspirit44 How lovely to sing Poulenc's Gloria. That, with the Stabat Mater, is one of my two or three favourite CDs.
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Because I had to give up driving about 25 years ago, walking is something I do all the time! With this latest cancer needing Letrozole but no surgery, I have been abel to keep up walking as usual. If it is  raining, I do my physio exercises at home,  in order to keep dodgy hip supported.  I always take a walking stick though.
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Karebear I'm not sure which make I wear but I've been wearing good trainers since my sight loss 20 years ago. I do not buy any other shoes(!!) so I don't care what they cost - last pair about £140 I think. Make sure that the INSIDE is  smooth and without any seams or hard bits which could cause corns on your toes. One of the reasons I always wear trainers is that if I accidentally step on something which could cause me to lose balance or turn my ankle, I have the much wider heel base to prevent this. I also take a walking stick, but that's mainly for balance because of having only some peripheral vision to the right. Good luck with the walking and, of course, good news on all your future chek-ups.
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Fingers crossed that this post appears at the end of the topic!! That is because clicking on 'view last post' has still taken me to the first!. I follow the e-mails as usual but have no BC news to report - my next check is in September, but in the meantime, I've bbbeen having some dizziness and low blood pressure to deal with. I admire the way you photograph and keep each other's spirits up. Can't  put the 'b' in the word been!
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Hi Happybird I too see The Needles - I didn't know they had a nickname!  - when I go out for my walk. I live in New Milton and go down to Barton  . and walk along Marine Drive!
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Violet Sith I think you are right about people here supporting each other, especially when having to have chemo, etc. I read the e-mail notifications daily.  For me, the walking is getting easier because of being back on betablockers, but I'm hoping to be able to push myself a little harder when I've had the MRI scan on 15th. This is to see the condition of my heart, but since they're going to pass the breast tumour  on the way down, I hope they will notice if there's anything else around that shouldn't be there! I can't comment on the photos, but from what you all say, they sound lovely!
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Cannon Thank you - it will be interesting to see what the changed medication will be.
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Yes, it is definitely those friendly exchanges of just a word or two which make one's day. I have a check-up tomorrow, but the transport arrived this afternoon. I'd had a letter about ten days ago saying the apt had been changed. The driver reported back, the transport organisers phoned me and the girl, when she realised even copying down a phone number is a bit tricky said she would deal with it and phone me back, which she did. Now, that was something I really appreciated and took away the worry that might have ensued if I'd  had to do it myself. I have as always been following everybody's news on the e-mail notifications, and I do so admire the way you are all coping. I think the check-up willshow that the lump is probably a fraction smaller, but will post again later in the week.
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: It is really interesting following all the posts here via the e-mnail notifications.  The positive attitude is lovely. I'm finding that the Letrozole are causing some muscle fatigue, and when I'm out, I have to stop and have arrest occasionally. Well, I can't be putting up with that, for goodness' sake!!  I'm seeing the Surgeon on 21st March about all the side effects.
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Oh dear - double posted - it did not seem to have gone when I clicked post. Apologies!!
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: LeoLady Very sorry to hear you were unwell.  Take care. I echo the good wishes in above posts (seen via e-mail notifications as usual).
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: good gracious! I've just managed to find the double arrows to go to last post!! I was unable to go to page to fill in details of problem so thought I'd just click through all hundred plus pages to get to the end!! But not necessary after all! I am sure those who read only must constantly feel encouraged by your posts and pictures. huggy person, but I like the way endings are often 'hugs'!! :)
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: That is interesting about rehydration sachets, moomy. I don't think I have ever heard of those - will ask at pharmacy tomorrow.
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Thoughts for all those having chemo. I know quite a  few who have had it although I have been fortunate not to. Walking certainly needs to be undertaken early, I think. I went out at  about 7:40 a.m. yesterday. By the way, a word of caution on the fluid intake - I thought I was doing the right thing but found out that I was drinking too much and washing away my potassium - or something like that. One of the common things old people do it seems!!
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Cannon That is very kind of you to say. I have been reading this thread daily and always find it interesting. I so admire the way everybody here is positive and supportive of everyone else. this is also true of all the other threads I think. I did not like being stuck indoors because of the gloom and drizzle! I did manage to get out a few times and am training myself to walk slowly!!  Chest clinic on 12th, then I'll know more about what my heart is doing.
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Moomy Good luck with the Letrozole - I shall be interested to know if you get any side effects. The partial loss of upperlip hair, thinning of eyebrows and eyelashes, only started after 9 months. Otherwise I find them easy to take. How lovely to have a sunny day today. I walked round the block this morning and this afternoon went to the |Leisure Centre for my swimming time. I was a bit wary, but had no dizziness or tightness in chest, so was very cheered. Perhaps the beta blockers have already started to work.
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Merry Christmas - and there was a post up-thread thanking LeoLady for this topic and it sounds as if we all agree with that!
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: What happened If you are a few years older than me then I hope you give yourself fullcredit for being so clear-thinking and adept on the computer and the internet! When I was in hospital just before Christmas there was a woman in the bed opposite me and in conversation, it turned out that we probably knew each other from a Rambers Group years ago. Anyway, she is 91 , alert and agile and had had a minor heart blip. It is the genetics we are born with!I am lucky in that my weight has tended to drop off rather than go on. I had to have a new passport photo done recently (for renewal of the blue badge I'm entitled to) and even though I could only rather vaguely see the photo on the CTV, it gave me quite  a shock!!!
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: What happened I think I might have got wires crossed a bit here! I am nearly 83 and from your above post it sounds as if you are still amere child, i.e. in your 50s!! Please clarify! Especially as you said your mother called...... Was it a typo I made?!! It is a very grey day here, but I am hoping it will brighten up a bit as I do like to get a walk in on a Sunday.
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Reading with interest as always - via e-mail notifications. Had ten days with software on the blink, but okay again now. Alexa not playing Radio 4 but at least that means I have avoided the constant same old news!
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: It is as always good to read the e-mail notifications of all the things  you all doo especially for those who are still undergoing various treatments. I went to see the Surgeon today and she has decided to remove the lump under a local anaesthetic. I think the last time I posted, I might have mentioned that it feels a bit knobblier! As I have to take so many blood thinners, it will make things a bit more difficult for her, but I suppose I'll be better off without the lump.   It might slow me down at tap dancing a bit for a week or two though! Good wishes and thoughts to all. Susans
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: My thanks for kind thoughts above. I do hope the City Council preserve your allotments, WhatHappened. With the latest news pointing out that the way farming is done these days is helping to reduce diversity, it is madness to concrete over yet another piece of food-producing and personally and caringly managed piece of land.
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Regarding exercise: In my early 40s I walked up the cliff at Lulworth Cove and was horrified to find myself having to pause and get my breath. That was the final straw that sent me to find a gym! I have included exercise in my life ever since. It certainly helps when health issues crop up. Once into that way of life, and knowing how much better you feel, it is  something that you know you have to keep up. I've been there this morning - being a bit cautious because my heart is apparently running out of unclogged arteries!
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Violetsmiff Posting to say 'thirded' to your post above about thanking people for this thread. I can't comment on the  photos, but to read the daily e-mail notifications of the encouragement and positive attitude as well as the support everyone gives everyone else is just lovely and I so much admire all here. My lump seems to have become slightly knobblier! but remains smaller than it was which is just as well since I am, as I thought, managing on one-and-a-half coronary arteries! Actually, it was quite funny. I had a letter from hospital offering me a follow-up appointment in the Gastroenterology Dept! I was seeing the GP on Friday so showed him the letter. He was very surprised! I checked with the hospital and apparently the Consultant in that dept and also the Cardiology dept have similar initials and the appointment boooking dept had made a mistake. Just as well I enquired straight away!
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: does anyone here, I wonder,  know of a woman with a higherrisk of heart failure who has had a lumpectomy with a local anaesthetic? I googled it and there was some study comparing local anesthetic with general anaesthetic and as far as I could see, the results looked quite reasonable. I think it is excellent to hear of all the walking going on here! It doesn't look like rain here this morning, so I shall try and do the 2.3 miles around town plus coffee and toasted teacake at the end of course!
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Moomy, I am so sorry to hear about that. All of you here have more than enough to cope with having had surgery and then having to deal with the follow-up therapies and hospital visits. Such thoughtlessness on the part of that cyclist. I read all the posts with admiration and respect for you all. I know that I am sort of lucky that, although I had surgery 31 years ago,  I have not had to have surgery and that all I havde to do is swallow a pill every day.
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: good gracious! I've just managed to find the double arrows to go to last post!! I was unable to go to page to fill in details of problem so thought I'd just click through all hundred plus pages to get to the end!! But not necessary after all! I am sure those who read only must constantly feel encouraged by your posts and pictures. huggy person, but I like the way endings are often 'hugs'!! :)
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Ah, right, I've got it now. Need to wait a bit for reply to appear. I also now have SuperNova 17 which is compatible with Google Chrome, so I should be able to use that in future. Hmmm! Also I looked at 'Latest Activities' link for the first time jjust now!!
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Yesterday, 28th, I had my lumpectomy under a local anaesthetic. I cannot speak too highly of the whole thing. All the staff involved, particularly the surgeon of course, were excellent and being fully awake was no problem, especially as all was done and finished within 2.1/2 hours. I then had to wait another 2.1/2 hours for the transport home, but since there was zero pain, no bleeding, no drain, and NO DRESSING!! that was fine. They put a glue on which feels like a piece of sellotape. The tumour was about 2 cm long and it seems I will have to change medication because Letrozole has evidently ceased to be effective. But you know, I was just absolutely amazed at the whole thing. I slept well and just followed my normal routine this morning, including walking to towon. Okay, I did walk a bit more slowly, but that was because of heart, not the cancer. It is a pity the e-mail notifications are not working, isn't it, so I have to come here to see what everyone has been doing...
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: E-mail notifications not appearing recently, so posting mainly to make sure box is ticked to continue to receive them. Re lumpectomy under local anaesthetic next week: Does anybody have an idea of paint/soreness level post such an op?
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Ann Jac Catching up...  and have read your post about retirement and the posts about your career. That was so interesting and what an achievement! Enjoy retirement too
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Happybird Having started Letrozole last April, I had no side effects (except a few very low-key hot flushes) until a couple of months ago when I noticed upperlip hair, eyebrows and, just this week, realised eye lashes going. I see it is a rare side effect, but maybe something to keep in mind? I can cope with no upper lip hair or eyebrows, but I draw the line at no eye lashes! Another odd thing I noticed too. Being an ancient person, I have had some of those skin tags that old people get on their necks *smiley* but they have gone too!!
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: That is too much to have to cope with all at once, Ann Jac, and I am so sorry to hear about it. As far as which thread to put it on, I think you will probablyy find good advice here going from what I have been reading over the past year or so. All the best - and I do hope you have some better news soon/
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Cannon and Shimmering Unicorn As tap dancing is quite my favourite activity, the words tap dancing jump out at me!! SoI'd just like to say to Cannon, go for it! If you haven't done it before, you can't get worse!!! And it is worth every effort to learn and internalise the basic techniques. There are some amazing you tubes. I might have mentioned somewhere - I run a tap group on a Thursday, but I'll have to cancel today as there is snow around and there is no point in people driving in that.   The baby of the group is 72 and four of us are over 80!
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: I had no reason to go out on Wednesday, so now I have been stuck in the house for three and a half days! I had hoped the snow would keep off until Thursday afternoon, so we could still tap, but no such luck, and I had to cancel it. Today it is raining, but the snow and ice are clearing only slowly. so it is no good venturing out.
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Catching up on posts,  in order to hear about your Palace Garden Party day, Ann Jac. Sounds as if it memorable. And how lucky you were with the weather. Really nice to read about all other activities too. I've been on the Exemestane for several weeks now and the transition from Letrozole has been easy - no problems!
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: On Friday, I had a breast screening - mammogram and ultra-sound. I was impressed with the mammogram machine - much kinder to the boobs than the old ones.! The doctor who did the ultra-sound said it was difficult to see if the lump had got bigger, but it had changed shape a bit, so it will definitely be better out than in!  No walking today - a gale blowing out there!
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: catching up on reading posts; lovely to hear of holidays and walks; and much sympathy for healing setbaks. I was lucky today to hear, at post-op check, that the surgeon is confident that she got all the cancer out, there is no need for further visits and that check-ups six-monthly ones from now on. Different tablets (beginning with e) and take them for five years. I said I'd be very happy with that as by that time I'll be 88!
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Catching up on reading here - what a lovely Easter weekend for weather. A bit too windy to venture out today I think! I've had two doses of  antibiotics during the last two weeks because of a  chest infection so wanted to check my energy levels! I can still feela bit of stitch and/or superglue on wound, but will get someone to look at it before I go back to swimming.   I'm stil amazed at how little trouble it has  been.
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Fingers crossed, I am hoping this post will work My thanks for the replies that I have read.  Thanks to JasmineAdmin too - she might have already posted on my behalf. I will be back with proper responses as soon as possible.
Posts.Title: Living with Letrozole, as wel as breast cancer

Posts.Content: Jiowo                                                                            omot   Thank you for your reply. My goodness, that was awful for your aunt. But what an encouraging story of a shrinking tumour and an amazing rrecovery. Just goes to show how medical science has advanced. I might start planning an 85th cup of tea in four years time!
Posts.Title: Living with Letrozole, as wel as breast cancer

Posts.Content: Dreamthief   Thank you for your post and the offers of help. I have some peripheral vision – I’ll put info in profile. When I saw the Consultant on Monday, I asked about how often she would see me. The answer was: every three months for a year or two, and then we will probably be able to discharge you. Sounded promising. I see Heather has posted and I will respond a.s.a.p..
Posts.Title: Living with Letrozole, as wel as breast cancer

Posts.Content: I shall be interested to hear how many women, instead of having smallish breast tumour removed, have been advised to take Letrozole. It seems that the tumour is a 1-2, is  already shrinking a bit, is not doing anything, or going anywhere. I am 81 and keep fit. I had to ask for help registering because I am registered blind. I understand that the title 'Yellow roses' will appear, and I'll try and think of something to replace that later. I don't think that's quite me!) susan
Posts.Title: Living with Letrozole, as wel as breast cancer

Posts.Content: Heather77   Thank you so much for your very helpful post about your personal experience, much appreciated. I feel very well, fortunately, and keeping fit is important to me. Being a pedestrian, I probably walk more than quite a few people and on home ground I can move around quite well. If I am in strange, i.e. not known so well, surroundings, I need a guiding arm.
Posts.Title: Living with Letrozole, as wel as breast cancer

Posts.Content: Lavendergirl Thank you for your reply. It is interesting to hear a bout what others have done and how they have been affected. I'm really pleased I found this forum I'll have a go at putting some info in the profile page, but in the meantime I think I'll be called Ancient tapper. That is because my favourite hobby is tap dancing. Of which nore later!!
Posts.Title: Living with Letrozole, as wel as breast cancer

Posts.Content: AngelaA   Thank you for the welcome. On other forums I just use my first and second names (SusanDoris) and I’m hopeless at thinking up anything clever! The only thing that springs to mindm, as I have said above, is Ancient Tapper, so that will robably be the one I shall choose!
Posts.Title: Living with Letrozole, as wel as breast cancer

Posts.Content: I'm sure you have done the right thing by coming to this forum for a start! I read all the posts on the Walking Back to Happiness thread and am so very admiring of the support and encouragement given to each other by posters. The warmth and care for others shines out. I have a lump which has reduced in size with Letrozole and although I had radiotherapy 30-odd years ago with the first breast cancer, I have never had chemo. I know and hear about many who do and it certainly seems to be very effective. All the very best of luck..
Posts.Title: Breast cancer diagnosis and terrified of chemotherapy and radiotherapy...
